perturbation.original_text: The Parties agree that and acknowledge that the relationship of the Parties is in the nature of an independent contractor. This Agreement shall not be deemed to create a partnership or joint venture and neither Party is the other's agent, partner, employee or representative.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties agree that and acknowledge that the relationship of the Parties is in the nature of an independent worker. This Agreement shall not be deemed to create a partnership or joint venture and neither Party is the other's agent, partner, employee or representative.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "independent contractor" to "independent worker" introduces ambiguity. While the contract intends to establish an independent contractor relationship (defined under common and statutory law), "worker" is a broader term. Some jurisdictions differentiate between "worker" and "independent contractor," particularly regarding employment benefits and liabilities. This alteration creates uncertainty regarding the nature of the relationship.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Definition of Independent Contractor vs. Employee

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall be governed and construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the State of New York applicable to contracts made and to be performed exclusively in that State without giving effect to the principles of conflict of laws.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall be governed and construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the State of New York applicable to contracts, possibly considering conflict of laws principles at the enforcer's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: By changing "without giving effect to the principles of conflict of laws" to "possibly considering conflict of laws principles at the enforcer's discretion", the predictability of legal interpretation is undermined. Standard contract law dictates a clear choice of law clause. Introducing discretion contradicts this, potentially invalidating the clause or leading to unpredictable enforcement based on subjective interpretation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Standard Contract Law and Choice of Law Principles

perturbation.original_text: Confidential Information shall not include information which can be demonstrated: (a) to have been rightfully in the possession of HDI from a source other than the Company prior to the time of disclosure of said information to HDI hereunder ("Time of Receipt"); (b) to have been in the public domain prior to the Time of Receipt; (c) to have become part of the public domain after the Time of Receipt by a publication or by any other means except an unauthorized act or omission or breach of this Agreement on the part of HDI, its employees, or agents; or (d) to have been supplied to HDI after the Time of Receipt by a third party who is under no obligation to the
perturbation.changed_text: Confidential Information may not include information which HDI claims: (a) to have been in the possession of HDI from any source; (b) to have been generally discussed before; (c) to have become generally discussed after disclosure; or (d) to have been supplied to HDI by some party.
perturbation.explanation: This alteration significantly weakens the definition of Confidential Information. Removing the burden of demonstration, removing Time of Receipt reference, and using ambiguous terms like 'generally discussed' and 'some party' makes it substantially harder to protect trade secrets. This contradicts standard legal definitions of confidential information and trade secret protection laws, allowing HDI broad leeway to claim information isn't confidential.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law and Standard Confidentiality Agreement Principles
